introduction.p: A simple example of a function is a temperature converter. It converts a temperature from degrees Fahrenheit to degrees Celsius.
The function is the rule or process used to convert from one unit of temperature to the other.

The graph illustrates that the temperature in degrees Celsius is a function of the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit.
The temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, F, is the input while the temperature in degrees Celsius, C, is the output.

li.p: Locate the input value of 77 degrees Fahrenheit along the horizontal axis, and find the point on the graph directly above this input value. What is the output value when the input is 77?

Locate the output value of -22 degrees Celsius along the vertical axis, and find the point on the graph directly to the left of this output value. What is the input value which gives the output of -22?

solution.p: To graphically find these answers, visualize arrows and guidelines on the graph. To find the Celsius equivalent of 77 degrees Fahrenheit, recognize that 77 is an input value, and so you must identify it on the horizontal axis. From there, move up, then left to the vertical axis, where you land at about 25 degrees Celsius. So 77 \text{degrees Fahrenheit} \approx25 \text{degrees Celsius}.

A similar process in reverse is used to determine the Fahrenheit temperature equivalent of -22 degrees Celsius. Recognize that -22 is an output, and so you must identify it on the vertical axis. From there, move left, then up to the horizontal axis, where you land at about -8 degrees Fahrenheit. So the answer is F\approx-8.

subsection.title: How to Determine if a Relation is a Function or Not
subsection.p: When two or more variables are related to each other, the formula or rule that relates them is called a relation. For people, there is a relation between age and height. You can make ordered pairs of (\text{age}, \text{height}) for different people and plot the points on a graph. You might even find a formula that predicts height based on age (or vice versa?)

In every relation you have encountered so far in this chapter, each input gives you only one output. For the train example we saw earlier, we had the function D = f(t). At any given time, like t = 10, the train can only be in one place, f(10). It's not possible for the train to be in two or more places at the same time.

Also, notice that each input has its own unique output. Every day at t = 10, the train is always in the same place: f(10) = 30 (it's a very dependable train). These two conditions make the relation a function. Position is a function of time.
But not all relations are functions. Just because two things are related does not mean one is a function of the other.

Twice each day, the train is 30 miles away from downtown once in the morning on its way out, then later in the afternoon on the way back into town. If we choose position as input and time as output, we realize that the input D = 30 gives us two answers: one time in the morning and another in the afternoon. Thus time is not a function of position. All we have is a relation.

hint.p: In each case, ask yourself what happens when you choose a value for the input x. Do you get one output or do you get more than one output?
If the relation is a function, then choosing a value of x will give you only one output value, y.

li.p: If y = x^2, then is y a function of x?
Yes, y is a function of x, because for any value of x you choose, there is only one possible y as a result.
If y^2 = x, then is y a function of x?
No, y is not function of x. When you choose a value for x, solving for y gives y = \pm \sqrt{x}.
This means that a single input will give you two outputs impossible for a function.

subsection.p: It is easy to tell whether a graph represents a function or not. Remember that the inputs are found along the horizontal axis, and the outputs are found along the vertical axis. When deciding whether the graph is a function, the rule is the same: one input, one unique output.

subsection.p: The previous example leads us to a simple test we can use to determine if a graph is a function or not: The vertical line testvertical line test.

Given a graph, draw a vertical line through any place on the graph. If the vertical line crosses the graph at most one time (no matter where you draw the line), then the graph is a function. If the vertical line crosses the graph anywhere at more than one point, then the graph is not a function.

statement.p: Drag the input to change the position of the vertical line.
Does the line intersect the graph more than once? If so, it does not pass the vertical line test and the graph is not a function.

subsection.title: Evaluate
subsection.p: It is one thing to talk about The train's distance from downtown 2 hours after 8 a.m. and a completely different thing to say what that distance actually is.

Evaluateevaluatefunctionevaluation means use an input value in order to find an output value. Therefore, evaluating f(2) in our train example means Find the value of the train's distance from downtown 2 hours after 8 a.m.
To evaluate f(2) we can use a graph, a table or a formula if they are available.
The important thing is we need some input value (time) to determine the output value for the train's distance from downtown. Remember: each individual input always gives the same single result.

statement.p: Remember that in a vertical table, the inputs are found in the left column (independent variable) while outputs are found in the right column (dependent variable)
Use the table to evaluate f(2.5)

subsection.p: In general when the inputs and outputs are nothing in particular, we use x as input and y as output so that y = f(x). We use x as a placeholder for the actual input value, while y is a placeholder for whatever the output value will be. The x basically says, When you get the input, put it here in all the places where the x is found.
Consider the function f(x) = 50x + 10. The function has no context (no story), so we won't bother using units for either x or y.
If x = 1, then we can evaluate f(1) by replacing the x in the formula with a 1. Literally, f(1) means what you get when you put 1 in the place of x.
Similarly, if you change the input to x = 2, then you can evaluate the expression f(2), which is what you get when you put 2 in the place of x.

subsection.title: The Secret to Evaluating Anything (The Blank Method)
subsection.p: Function notation is a way to tell the reader information about the input and how to use it to generate an output. Again, the way it works is: f(\text{input})=\text{output} Whatever is in the parenthesis is the input.
The input can be a simple number like 2 or -4, or it can be a complicated expression like x^2 - x.
Your success in this course is almost entirely dependent on your understanding of this simple concept: The blank method.
When you see a formula like f(x) = x^2 - x. It means this:f(\text{blank}) = (\text{blank})^2 - (\text{blank})
At least, that's the way formulas really work.
Using this function as an example, f(5) means The formula with a 5 in it. Literally, it means place number 5 in all the blanks.
